0.2 Kinematics

0.2.1 Newton's Second Law

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, the second law states that the force F\mathbf{F}F acting on the particle is equal to the time derivative of the momentum p\mathbf{p}p of the particle:

F=dpdt\mathbf{F} = \frac{d\mathbf{p}}{dt}F=dtdp​

If the mass of the particle is constant, then the second law can be written in terms of the acceleration a\mathbf{a}a of the particle:

F=ma\mathbf{F} = m\mathbf{a}F=ma

0.2.2 Inertial Frames and Galileo Transformation

Given a frame of reference S\mathbf{S}S and another frame of reference S′\mathbf{S}'S′ moving with equation of motion s=s(t)\mathbf{s} = \mathbf{s}(t)s=s(t) with respect to S\mathbf{S}S, and rotation with respect to S\mathbf{S}S with orthogonal matrix O(t)\mathbf{O}(t)O(t), the transformation of the position vector r′\mathbf{r}'r′ in S′\mathbf{S}'S′ to r\mathbf{r}r in S\mathbf{S}S is given by:

r=O(t)r′+s(t)\mathbf{r} = O(t)\mathbf{r}' + \mathbf{s}(t)r=O(t)r′+s(t)

And the transformation of the force F′\mathbf{F}'F′ in S′\mathbf{S}'S′ to F\mathbf{F}F in S\mathbf{S}S is given by:

F=O(t)F′\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{O}(t)\mathbf{F}'F=O(t)F′

Assume in S\mathbf{S}S, the second law holds, then in S′\mathbf{S}'S′:

mr¨=O¨r′+2O˙r′˙+r′¨O+s¨=F≠O(t)F′m\ddot{\mathbf{r}} = \ddot{\mathbf{O}}\mathbf{r'} + 2\dot{\mathbf{O}}\dot{\mathbf{r}'} + \ddot{\mathbf{r}'}\mathbf{O} + \ddot{\mathbf{s}} = \mathbf{F} \neq \mathbf{O}(t)\mathbf{F}'mr¨=O¨r′+2O˙r′˙+r′¨O+s¨=F=O(t)F′

However, if O\mathbf{O}O is a constant orthogonal matrix, and s\mathbf{s}s is a linear function of time, then the second law holds in S′\mathbf{S}'S′. Such frames are called inertial frames. And the corresponding transformation is called Galileo transformation.

0.2.3 Momentum Conservation

Given a system of particles, the total momentum P\mathbf{P}P of the system is given by:

P=∑ipi\mathbf{P} = \sum_i \mathbf{p}_iP=i∑​pi​

If the net external force acting on the system is zero, then the total momentum of the system is conserved:

dPdt=∑idpidt=∑iFi=Fext=0\frac{d\mathbf{P}}{dt} = \sum_i \frac{d\mathbf{p}_i}{dt} = \sum_i \mathbf{F}_i = \mathbf{F}_{\text{ext}} = 0dtdP​=i∑​dtdpi​​=i∑​Fi​=Fext​=0

0.2.3.1 Momentum Conservation in specific directions

Given a constant vector a\mathbf{a}a, if the net external force acting on the system is zero in the direction of a\mathbf{a}a, then the total momentum of the system in the direction of a\mathbf{a}a is conserved:

ddt(∑ipi⋅a)=∑iFi⋅a=Fext⋅a=0\frac{d}{dt}\left(\sum_i \mathbf{p}_i\cdot\mathbf{a}\right) = \sum_i \mathbf{F}_i\cdot\mathbf{a} = \mathbf{F}_{\text{ext}}\cdot\mathbf{a} = 0dtd​(i∑​pi​⋅a)=i∑​Fi​⋅a=Fext​⋅a=0

0.2.4 Angular Momentum

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, the angular momentum L\mathbf{L}L of the particle with respect to the origin is given by:

L=r×p\mathbf{L} = \mathbf{r}\times\mathbf{p}L=r×p

0.2.5 Torque (Moment of Force)

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, and a force F\mathbf{F}F acting on the particle, the torque τ\mathbf{\tau}τ of the particle with respect to the origin is given by:

τ=r×F\mathbf{\tau} = \mathbf{r}\times\mathbf{F}τ=r×F

The torque represent the tendency of the force to rotate the particle.

0.2.5.1 Torque and Angular Momentum

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, and a force F\mathbf{F}F acting on the particle, the time derivative of the angular momentum L\mathbf{L}L of the particle with respect to the origin is given by:

dLdt=r×F=τ\frac{d\mathbf{L}}{dt} = \mathbf{r}\times\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{\tau}dtdL​=r×F=τ

0.2.6 Angular Momentum Conservation

Given a system of particles, the total angular momentum L\mathbf{L}L of the system with respect to the origin is given by:

L=∑iLi=∑iri×pi\mathbf{L} = \sum_i \mathbf{L}_i = \sum_i \mathbf{r}_i\times\mathbf{p}_iL=i∑​Li​=i∑​ri​×pi​

If the net external torque acting on the system is zero, then the total angular momentum of the system is conserved:

dLdt=∑idLidt=∑iτi=τext=0\frac{d\mathbf{L}}{dt} = \sum_i \frac{d\mathbf{L}_i}{dt} = \sum_i \mathbf{\tau}_i = \mathbf{\tau}_{\text{ext}} = 0dtdL​=i∑​dtdLi​​=i∑​τi​=τext​=0

0.2.6.1 Angular momentum conservation in specific directions

Given a constant vector a\mathbf{a}a, if the net external torque acting on the system is zero in the direction of a\mathbf{a}a, then the total angular momentum of the system in the direction of a\mathbf{a}a is conserved:

ddt(∑iLi⋅a)=∑iτi⋅a=τext⋅a=0\frac{d}{dt}\left(\sum_i \mathbf{L}_i\cdot\mathbf{a}\right) = \sum_i \mathbf{\tau}_i\cdot\mathbf{a} = \mathbf{\tau}_{\text{ext}}\cdot\mathbf{a} = 0dtd​(i∑​Li​⋅a)=i∑​τi​⋅a=τext​⋅a=0

0.3 Forces

0.3.1 Newton's Third Law

Given two particles iii and jjj with forces Fij\mathbf{F}_{ij}Fij​ and Fji\mathbf{F}_{ji}Fji​ acting on them, the third law states that the forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction:

Fij=−Fji\mathbf{F}_{ij} = -\mathbf{F}_{ji}Fij​=−Fji​

0.3.2 Gravity

Given two particles iii and jjj with masses mim_imi​ and mjm_jmj​ and position vectors ri\mathbf{r}_iri​ and rj\mathbf{r}_jrj​,

the gravitational force Fij\mathbf{F}_{ij}Fij​ acting on particle iii due to particle jjj is given by:

Fij=−Gmimj∣ri−rj∣3(ri−rj)\mathbf{F}_{ij} = -\frac{Gm_im_j}{|\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{r}_j|^3}(\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{r}_j)Fij​=−∣ri​−rj​∣3Gmi​mj​​(ri​−rj​)

where GGG is the gravitational constant.

0.3.2.1 The Gravitational Constant

The gravitational constant GGG is a fundamental constant in physics. It is defined as the constant of proportionality in Newton's law of universal gravitation:

F=−Gm1m2r2r^\mathbf{F} = -\frac{Gm_1m_2}{r^2}\hat{\mathbf{r}}F=−r2Gm1​m2​​r^

where F\mathbf{F}F is the force between two point masses m1m_1m1​ and m2m_2m2​ separated by a distance rrr, and r^\hat{\mathbf{r}}r^ is the unit vector pointing from m1m_1m1​ to m2m_2m2​.

The value of GGG is approximately 6.67430×10−11 m3 kg−1 s−26.67430\times10^{-11}\,\text{m}^3\,\text{kg}^{-1}\,\text{s}^{-2}6.67430×10−11m3kg−1s−2.

0.3.2.2 Near Earth's Surface

Given a particle of mass mmm near the surface of the Earth with acceleration due to gravity ggg, the gravitational force Fg\mathbf{F}_gFg​ acting on the particle is given by:

Fg=−−Gm1m2r2r^\mathbf{F}_g = --\frac{Gm_1m_2}{r^2}\hat{\mathbf{r}}Fg​=−−r2Gm1​m2​​r^

where m1m_1m1​ is the mass of the Earth, m2m_2m2​ is the mass of the particle, and rrr is the distance between the particle and the center of the Earth.

As the particle is near the surface of the Earth, the distance rrr is approximately the radius of the Earth RRR. And the mass of the Earth is a constant m1=Mm_1 = Mm1​=M.

Therefore, the gravitational force Fg\mathbf{F}_gFg​ acting on the particle is given by:

Fg=−GMmR2r^\mathbf{F}_g = -\frac{GMm}{R^2}\hat{\mathbf{r}}Fg​=−R2GMm​r^

where MMM is the mass of the Earth.

Given the acceleration due to gravity g=GMR2g = \frac{GM}{R^2}g=R2GM​, the gravitational force Fg\mathbf{F}_gFg​ acting on the particle is given by:

Fg=−mgr^\mathbf{F}_g = -mg\hat{\mathbf{r}}Fg​=−mgr^

where ggg is the acceleration due to gravity. The common value of ggg is approximately 9.81 m/s29.81\,\text{m/s}^29.81m/s2.

0.3.3 Elastic Forces

The forces due to the tendency of a object to restore its original shape are called elastic forces.

0.3.3.1 Hooke's Law

Given a spring with spring constant kkk and displacement eee, the elastic force TTT acting on the spring is given by:

T=−keT = -keT=−ke

0.3.4 Contact Forces

The forces due to the contact of two objects are called contact forces.

Where RRR is the normal force, FFF is the frictional force.

0.3.4.1 Moving Friction

Given a moving object on a surface with coefficient of kinetic friction μk\mu_kμk​, and normal force RRR acting on the object, the frictional force FkF_kFk​ acting on the object is given by:

Fk=−μkRF_k = -\mu_k RFk​=−μk​R

0.4 Work and Energy

0.4.1 Potential Energy

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, the potential energy UUU of the particle is given by:

U=U(r)U = U(\mathbf{r})U=U(r)

and the force F\mathbf{F}F acting on the particle is given by:

F=−∇U\mathbf{F} = -\nabla UF=−∇U

Consequently, the potential energy UUU can be expressed in terms of the force F\mathbf{F}F acting on the particle:

U=−∫F⋅drU = -\int \mathbf{F}\cdot d\mathbf{r}U=−∫F⋅dr

0.4.2 Energy Conservation

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, the total energy EEE of the particle is given by:

E=T+UE = T + UE=T+U

where TTT is the kinetic energy of the particle, and UUU is the potential energy of the particle.

If the net external force acting on the particle is zero, then the total energy of the particle is conserved:

dEdt=dTdt+dUdt=ddt(12mv⋅v)−∇Udrdt=ddt(12mv2)−∇U⋅v=mv⋅a−F⋅v=F⋅v−F⋅v=0\begin{align} \frac{dE}{dt} &= \frac{dT}{dt} + \frac{dU}{dt} \\ &= \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{1}{2}mv\cdot v\right) -\nabla U \frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt} \\ &= \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{1}{2}mv^2\right) -\nabla U \cdot \mathbf{v} \\ &= m\mathbf{v}\cdot\mathbf{a} - \mathbf{F}\cdot\mathbf{v} \\ &= \mathbf{F}\cdot\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{F}\cdot\mathbf{v} \\ &= 0 \end{align}dtdE​​=dtdT​+dtdU​=dtd​(21​mv⋅v)−∇Udtdr​=dtd​(21​mv2)−∇U⋅v=mv⋅a−F⋅v=F⋅v−F⋅v=0​​

0.4.2.1 Conservative Forces

Given a force F\mathbf{F}F acting on a particle, if the force is conservative, then the force can be expressed as the gradient of a scalar function:

F=−∇U\mathbf{F} = -\nabla UF=−∇U

where UUU is the potential energy of the particle.

For conservative forces, on a simply connected domain (the domain is path connected and any closed curve can be shrunk to a point without leaving the domain), the work done by the force F\mathbf{F}F on the particle is path independent:

∫r1r2F⋅dr=U(r1)−U(r2)\int_{\mathbf{r}_1}^{\mathbf{r}_2} \mathbf{F}\cdot d\mathbf{r} = U(\mathbf{r}_1) - U(\mathbf{r}_2)∫r1​r2​​F⋅dr=U(r1​)−U(r2​)
0.4.2.1.1 Example: Non-conservative Forces

Given a force F\mathbf{F}F acting on a particle, where the force can be expressed as:

F(x,y,z)=(0,0,x)\mathbf{F}(x,y,z) = (0,0,x)F(x,y,z)=(0,0,x)

by solving the PDE, there is no potential energy UUU such that:

F=−∇U\mathbf{F} = -\nabla UF=−∇U

Thus, the force F\mathbf{F}F is non-conservative.

0.4.2.1.2 Essential Conditions for Conservative Forces

Given a force F\mathbf{F}F acting on a particle, the force is conservative if the following conditions are satisfied:

  1. The force F\mathbf{F}F is a function of the position vector r\mathbf{r}r only.

  2. The force F\mathbf{F}F is irrotational, that is, the curl of the force is zero:

    ∇×F=0\nabla\times\mathbf{F} = 0∇×F=0

0.4.2.2 Qualitative Energy Analysis

At point x1x_{1}x1​, the particle has speed x˙=0\dot{x} = 0x˙=0 and potential energy V′(x)<0V'(x) < 0V′(x)<0. Thus, the particle has to move to the right.

At point x2x_{2}x2​, the particle has speed x˙=0\dot{x} = 0x˙=0 and potential energy V′(x)>0V'(x) > 0V′(x)>0. Thus, the particle has to move to the left.

If the initial position of the particle is inside [x1,x2][x_{1},x_{2}][x1​,x2​], then the particle will oscillate between x1x_{1}x1​ and x2x_{2}x2​. As it can not go beyond x1x_{1}x1​ and x2x_{2}x2​.

As when x→∞x \rightarrow \inftyx→∞, the potential energy V(x)→0V(x) \rightarrow 0V(x)→0, the speed of the particle x˙→2Em\dot{x} \rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{2E}{m}}x˙→m2E​​.

0.4.3 Work

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, the work WWW done by a force F\mathbf{F}F on the particle along a path CCC is given by:

W=∫CF⋅drW = \int_C \mathbf{F}\cdot d\mathbf{r}W=∫C​F⋅dr

0.4.3.1 Work and Kinetic Energy

Given a particle of mass mmm and position vector r\mathbf{r}r, the work WWW done by a force F\mathbf{F}F on the particle is equal to the change in kinetic energy TTT of the particle:

T(t1)−T(t0)=W=∫t0t1F⋅vdtT(t_{1}) - T(t_{0}) = W = \int_{t_{0}}^{t_{1}} \mathbf{F}\cdot\mathbf{v} dtT(t1​)−T(t0​)=W=∫t0​t1​​F⋅vdt

0.5 Lagrangian Mechanics

If we are working with some coordinate that are not Cartesian (e.g. Polar Coordinate), we can use the Lagrangian mechanics to describe the motion of the system.

0.5.1 Lagrangian

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, as the system evolves in time, which means the generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​ are functions of time ttt, we are also given q˙i\dot{q}_{i}q˙​i​.

The Lagrangian LLL of the system is given by:

L=T−UL = T - UL=T−U

where TTT is the kinetic energy of the system, and UUU is the potential energy of the system, and both are functions of the generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​ and their time derivatives q˙i\dot{q}_{i}q˙​i​ and possibly time ttt.

0.5.2 Euler-Lagrange Equation

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, the Euler-Lagrange equation is given by:

ddt(∂L∂q˙i)−∂L∂qi=0\frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}} = 0dtd​(∂q˙​i​∂L​)−∂qi​∂L​=0

0.5.3 Action Integral

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, the action integral SSS of the system is given by:

S[q]=∫t0t1L(q,q˙,t)dtS[q] = \int_{t_{0}}^{t_{1}} L(q,\dot{q},t) dtS[q]=∫t0​t1​​L(q,q˙​,t)dt

0.5.4 Hamilton's Principle

The solution to the Euler-Lagrange equation is the path q(t)q(t)q(t) that is a stationary point of the action integral S[q]S[q]S[q].

0.5.5 Geodesic Equation

Given a arbitrary manifold. Given two point ppp and qqq on the manifold, and a curve γ\gammaγ connecting ppp and qqq.

If the length of the curve γ\gammaγ is given by the integral:

L[γ]=∫01g(γ)dtL[\gamma] = \int_{0}^{1} g(\gamma) dtL[γ]=∫01​g(γ)dt

for some function ggg.

And we wish to find the curve γ\gammaγ that minimizes the length L[γ]L[\gamma]L[γ].

The curve γ\gammaγ that minimizes the length L[γ]L[\gamma]L[γ] is called the geodesic.

If we define the Lagrangian LLL as:

L=g(γ,γ˙)L = g(\gamma,\dot{\gamma})L=g(γ,γ˙​)

Then the Euler-Lagrange equation is the geodesic equation.

0.5.6 Generalised Coordinates in Lagrangian Mechanics

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​.

The velocity of the particle is given by:

v=∑iq˙i\mathbf{v} = \sum_i \dot{q}_{i}v=i∑​q˙​i​

The momentum of the particle is given by:

p=∑i∂L∂q˙i\mathbf{p} = \sum_i \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}p=i∑​∂q˙​i​∂L​

The force acting on the particle is given by:

F=∑i∂L∂qi\mathbf{F} = \sum_i \frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}F=i∑​∂qi​∂L​

0.5.6.1 Cyclical Coordinates

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, if the Lagrangian LLL does not depend on a generalized coordinate qiq_iqi​, then the generalized coordinate qiq_iqi​ is called a cyclical coordinate.

If the Lagrangian LLL does not depend on a cyclical coordinate qiq_iqi​, then the momentum ∂L∂q˙i\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}∂q˙​i​∂L​ is conserved. Which means ∂L∂q˙i\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}∂q˙​i​∂L​ is a constant.

0.5.7 Example: Central Force

Given a particle of mass mmm moving in a plane with polar coordinates (r,θ)(r,\theta)(r,θ), with potential energy U(r)U(r)U(r) that depends only on the distance rrr from the origin,

As, the potential is independent of the angle θ\thetaθ, the force acting on the particle is radial.

The Lagrangian LLL of the particle is given by:

L=12m(r˙2+r2θ˙2)−U(r)L = \frac{1}{2}m\left(\dot{r}^2 + r^2\dot{\theta}^2\right) - U(r)L=21​m(r˙2+r2θ˙2)−U(r)

The Euler-Lagrange equation for the angular coordinate θ\thetaθ is given by:

ddt(∂L∂θ˙)−∂L∂θ=0ddt(mr2θ˙)=0mr2θ˙=J\begin{align} \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta} &= 0 \\ \frac{d}{dt}\left(mr^2\dot{\theta}\right) &= 0 \\ mr^2 \dot{\theta} = J \end{align}dtd​(∂θ˙∂L​)−∂θ∂L​dtd​(mr2θ˙)mr2θ˙=J​=0=0​​

We usually call JJJ the angular momentum of the particle. And in the central force situation the angular momentum is conserved.

The Euler-Lagrange equation for the radial coordinate rrr is given by:

ddt(∂L∂r˙)−∂L∂r=0ddt(mr˙)−mθ˙2r=−dUdrmr¨−mθ˙2r=−dUdrmr¨=J2mr3−dUdr\begin{align} \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial r} &= 0 \\ \frac{d}{dt}\left(m\dot{r}\right) - m\dot{\theta}^2r &= -\frac{dU}{dr} \\ m\ddot{r} - m\dot{\theta}^2r &= -\frac{dU}{dr} \\ m\ddot{r} &= \frac{J^2}{mr^3} -\frac{dU}{dr} \end{align}dtd​(∂r˙∂L​)−∂r∂L​dtd​(mr˙)−mθ˙2rmr¨−mθ˙2rmr¨​=0=−drdU​=−drdU​=mr3J2​−drdU​​​

The energy of the particle is given by:

E=12m(r˙2+r2θ˙2)+U(r)E = \frac{1}{2}m\left(\dot{r}^2 + r^2\dot{\theta}^2\right) + U(r)E=21​m(r˙2+r2θ˙2)+U(r)

And as:

dEdt=ddt(12mr˙2+12mr2θ˙2+U(r))=ddt(12mr˙2+12J2mr2+U(r))=mr˙r¨−J2mr3r˙+dUdrr˙=0\begin{align} \frac{dE}{dt} &= \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{1}{2}m\dot{r}^2 + \frac{1}{2}mr^2\dot{\theta}^2 + U(r)\right) \\ &= \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{1}{2}m\dot{r}^2 + \frac{1}{2}\frac{J^2}{mr^2} + U(r)\right) \\ &= m\dot{r}\ddot{r} - \frac{J^2}{mr^3}\dot{r} + \frac{dU}{dr}\dot{r} \\ &= 0 \end{align}dtdE​​=dtd​(21​mr˙2+21​mr2θ˙2+U(r))=dtd​(21​mr˙2+21​mr2J2​+U(r))=mr˙r¨−mr3J2​r˙+drdU​r˙=0​​

The energy of the particle is conserved. And we usually call EEE the total energy of the particle. And also the effective potential:

Ueff(r)=U(r)+J22mr2U_{\text{eff}}(r) = U(r) + \frac{J^2}{2mr^2}Ueff​(r)=U(r)+2mr2J2​

If we are give the effective potential Ueff(r)U_{\text{eff}}(r)Ueff​(r), the energy and angular momentum of the particle, then the equation of motion of the particle can be determined by solving two first order ODEs:

E0=12mr˙2+Ueff(r)J=mr2θ˙\begin{align} E_{0} &= \frac{1}{2}m\dot{r}^2 + U_{\text{eff}}(r) \\ J &= mr^2\dot{\theta} \end{align}E0​J​=21​mr˙2+Ueff​(r)=mr2θ˙​​

0.5.8 Lagrangian Mechanics with Constraints

0.5.8.1 Holonomic Constraints

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, if the generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​ are subject to constraints f(q1,…,qi,t)=0f(q_1,\dots,q_i,t) = 0f(q1​,…,qi​,t)=0, then the constraints are called holonomic constraints.

Any constraints that can not be expressed in the form f(q1,…,qi,t)=0f(q_1,\dots,q_i,t) = 0f(q1​,…,qi​,t)=0 are called non-holonomic constraints.

Example: Object with air resistance is a non-holonomic constraint, as the air resistance is independent of the speed of the object.

0.5.8.1.1 Unforced or Natural Constraints

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, if the constraints fj(qi,t)=0f_j(q_i,t) = 0fj​(qi​,t)=0 are independent of the time ttt, then the constraints are called unforced or natural constraints.

Example: A particle moving on a sphere of radius RRR.

Example: A pendulum with fixed suspension point.

0.5.8.1.2 Forced Constraints

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, if the constraints fj(qi,t)=0f_j(q_i,t) = 0fj​(qi​,t)=0 are dependent of the time ttt, then the constraints are called forced constraints.

Example: A particle moving on a sphere of radius RRR with the sphere rotating.

Example: A pendulum with the suspension point moving.

0.5.9 System of Particles and Rigid Bodies

0.5.9.1 Centre of Mass

Given a system of particles with masses mim_imi​ and position vectors ri\mathbf{r}_iri​, the centre of mass R\mathbf{R}R of the system is given by:

R=∑imiri∑imi\mathbf{R} = \frac{\sum_i m_i\mathbf{r}_i}{\sum_i m_i}R=∑i​mi​∑i​mi​ri​​

0.5.9.2 Total Momentum

Given a system of particles with masses mim_imi​ and position vectors ri\mathbf{r}_iri​, the total momentum P\mathbf{P}P of the system is given by:

P=∑ipi=∑imivi=∑imir˙i=∑imiri˙=R˙∑imi\begin{align} \mathbf{P} &= \sum_i \mathbf{p}_i \\ &= \sum_i m_i\mathbf{v}_i \\ &= \sum_i m_i\dot{\mathbf{r}}_i \\ &= \dot{\sum_i m_i{\mathbf{r}}_i} \\ &= \dot{\mathbf{R}} \sum_i m_i \\ \end{align}P​=i∑​pi​=i∑​mi​vi​=i∑​mi​r˙i​=i∑​mi​ri​˙​=R˙i∑​mi​​​

0.5.9.3 Total Angular Momentum

Given a system of particles with masses mim_imi​ and position vectors ri\mathbf{r}_iri​, the total angular momentum L\mathbf{L}L of the system with respect to the origin is given by:

L=∑iLi=R×P+∑i(ri−R)×(pi−P)\begin{align} \mathbf{L} &= \sum_i \mathbf{L}_i \\ &= \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{P} + \sum_i (\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{R})\times (\mathbf{p}_i - \mathbf{P})\\ \end{align}L​=i∑​Li​=R×P+i∑​(ri​−R)×(pi​−P)​​

The term ∑i(ri−R)×(pi−P)\sum_i (\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{R})\times (\mathbf{p}_i - \mathbf{P})∑i​(ri​−R)×(pi​−P) is the angular momentum of the system with respect to the centre of mass.

0.5.9.4 Total Kinetic Energy

Given a system of particles with masses mim_imi​ and position vectors ri\mathbf{r}_iri​, and the total mass of the system MMM, the total kinetic energy TTT of the system is given by:

T=∑iTi=∑i12mivi⋅vi=12MR˙2+∑i12mi(r˙i−R˙)2\begin{align} T &= \sum_i T_i \\ &= \sum_i \frac{1}{2}m_i\mathbf{v}_i\cdot\mathbf{v}_i \\ &= \frac{1}{2} M \dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 + \sum_i \frac{1}{2}m_i(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_i - \dot{\mathbf{R}})^2 \\ \end{align}T​=i∑​Ti​=i∑​21​mi​vi​⋅vi​=21​MR˙2+i∑​21​mi​(r˙i​−R˙)2​​

The term ∑i12mi(r˙i−R˙)2\sum_i \frac{1}{2}m_i(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_i - \dot{\mathbf{R}})^2∑i​21​mi​(r˙i​−R˙)2 is the kinetic energy of the system with respect to the centre of mass.

0.5.9.5 Separable Potential Energy

Given a system of particles with masses mim_imi​ and position vectors ri\mathbf{r}_iri​, and the total mass of the system MMM, the total potential energy UUU of the system is given by:

U=∑iUi=∑iUi(ri)\begin{align} U &= \sum_i U_i \\ &= \sum_i U_i(\mathbf{r}_i) \end{align}U​=i∑​Ui​=i∑​Ui​(ri​)​​

If the potential energy UUU is separable, that is, the potential energy can be expressed as:

U=UR(R)+∑iUi(ri)U = U_{\mathbf{R}}(\mathbf{R}) + \sum_i U_i(\mathbf{r}_i)U=UR​(R)+i∑​Ui​(ri​)

Then the generalised coordinates qiq_iqi​ can be reformulated using the center of mass R\mathbf{R}R and the relative coordinates ri−R\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{R}ri​−R. And the Lagrangian LLL can be expressed in terms of the center of mass R\mathbf{R}R and the relative coordinates ri−R\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{R}ri​−R.

L0=T0−U0=12MR˙2−UR(R)Li=Ti−Ui=12mi(r˙i−R˙)2−Ui(ri−R)\begin{align} L_{0} &= T_{0} - U_{0} = \frac{1}{2}M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 - U_{\mathbf{R}}(\mathbf{R}) \\ L_{i} &= T_{i} - U_{i} = \frac{1}{2}m_i(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_i - \dot{\mathbf{R}})^2 - U_i(\mathbf{r}_i-\mathbf{R}) \end{align}L0​Li​​=T0​−U0​=21​MR˙2−UR​(R)=Ti​−Ui​=21​mi​(r˙i​−R˙)2−Ui​(ri​−R)​​

Example: A constant gravitational field acting on a system of particles is a separable potential energy. And the total potential energy UUU of the system is given by: U=UR(R)U = U_{\mathbf{R}}(\mathbf{R})U=UR​(R), which only depend on the center of mass R\mathbf{R}R.

0.5.9.5.1 Example: Two Particles

Given two particles 111 and 222 with masses m1m_1m1​ and m2m_2m2​ and position vectors r1\mathbf{r}_1r1​ and r2\mathbf{r}_2r2​,

Then let:

R=m1r1+m2r2m1+m2r=r2−r1\begin{align} \mathbf{R} &= \frac{m_1\mathbf{r}_1 + m_2\mathbf{r}_2}{m_1 + m_2} \\ \mathbf{r} &= \mathbf{r}_2 - \mathbf{r}_1 \end{align}Rr​=m1​+m2​m1​r1​+m2​r2​​=r2​−r1​​​

Thus,

r1=R−m2m1+m2rr2=R+m1m1+m2r\begin{align} \mathbf{r}_1 &= \mathbf{R} - \frac{m_2}{m_1 + m_2}\mathbf{r} \\ \mathbf{r}_2 &= \mathbf{R} + \frac{m_1}{m_1 + m_2}\mathbf{r} \end{align}r1​r2​​=R−m1​+m2​m2​​r=R+m1​+m2​m1​​r​​

The kinetic energy TTT of the system is given by:

T=12MR˙2+[12m1(r˙2−R˙)2+12m2(r˙2−R˙)2]=12MR˙2+12m1m2m1+m2r˙2\begin{align} T &= \frac{1}{2}M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 + \left[\frac{1}{2}m_{1}(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}-\dot{\mathbf{R}})^2 + \frac{1}{2}m_{2}(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}-\dot{\mathbf{R}})^2 \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{2}M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 + \frac{1}{2}\frac{m_1m_2}{m_1+m_2}\dot{\mathbf{r}}^2 \end{align}T​=21​MR˙2+[21​m1​(r˙2​−R˙)2+21​m2​(r˙2​−R˙)2]=21​MR˙2+21​m1​+m2​m1​m2​​r˙2​​

And the potential is given by:

U=Ur(r)U = U_{\mathbf{r}}(\mathbf{r})U=Ur​(r)

Thus, the Lagrangian LLL of the system is given by:

L=12MR˙2+12m1m2m1+m2r˙2−Ur(r)L = \frac{1}{2}M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 + \frac{1}{2}\frac{m_1m_2}{m_1+m_2}\dot{\mathbf{r}}^2 - U_{\mathbf{r}}(\mathbf{r})L=21​MR˙2+21​m1​+m2​m1​m2​​r˙2−Ur​(r)

Apparently, the Lagrangian is cyclic in R\mathbf{R}R. Thus, the total momentum P\mathbf{P}P of the system is conserved.

0.5.9.6 Rigid Bodies

A rigid body is a system of particles with fixed relative distances between the particles.

For rigid body, we use R\mathbf{R}R to denote the position of the center of mass of the rigid body, and ρi=(ρi,φi)\mathbf{\rho}_i= (\rho_i, \varphi_i)ρi​=(ρi​,φi​) in polar coordinates to denote the position of the iii-th particle with respect to the center of mass.

As, the relative distances between the particles are fixed, ρi\rho_iρi​ is a constant of time. And also, the angular velocity φ˙i\dot{\varphi}_iφ˙​i​ is the same for all particles, in convention, we use φ˙i=φ\dot{\varphi}_i = \varphiφ˙​i​=φ to denote the angular velocity of the rigid body.

0.5.9.6.1 Moment of Inertia

Given a rigid body with mass MMM and position vector R\mathbf{R}R, and the iii-th particle with mass mim_imi​ and position vector ρi\mathbf{\rho}_iρi​, the kinetic energy TTT of the rigid body is given by:

T=12MR˙2+∑i12miρ˙i2=12MR˙2+∑i12mi(ρi2φ˙2)=12MR˙2+12φ˙2∑imiρi2\begin{align} T &= \frac{1}{2}M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 + \sum_i \frac{1}{2}m_i\dot{\mathbf{\rho}}_i^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2}M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 + \sum_i \frac{1}{2}m_i(\rho_i^2\dot{\varphi}^2) \\ &= \frac{1}{2}M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2 + \frac{1}{2} \dot{\varphi}^2 \sum_i m_i \rho_i^2 \end{align}T​=21​MR˙2+i∑​21​mi​ρ˙​i2​=21​MR˙2+i∑​21​mi​(ρi2​φ˙​2)=21​MR˙2+21​φ˙​2i∑​mi​ρi2​​​

The term ∑imiρi2\sum_i m_i \rho_i^2∑i​mi​ρi2​ is called the moment of inertia III of the rigid body, which represents the resistance of the rigid body to rotation.

0.5.9.6.1.1 Example: The moment of inertia of a homogeneous disk

Given a homogeneous disk of radius RRR and mass MMM, the moment of inertia III of the disk is given by:

I=∫02π∫0Rρ2ρMπR2dρdφ=MπR2∫02π∫0Rρ3dρdφ=MπR2∫02π14R4dφ=MπR22π14R4=12MR2\begin{align} I &= \int_{0}^{2\pi} \int_{0}^{R} \rho^2 \rho \frac{M}{\pi R^2} d\rho d\varphi \\ &= \frac{M}{\pi R^2} \int_{0}^{2\pi} \int_{0}^{R} \rho^3 d\rho d\varphi \\ &= \frac{M}{\pi R^2} \int_{0}^{2\pi} \frac{1}{4}R^4 d\varphi \\ &= \frac{M}{\pi R^2} 2\pi \frac{1}{4}R^4 \\ &= \frac{1}{2}MR^2 \end{align}I​=∫02π​∫0R​ρ2ρπR2M​dρdφ=πR2M​∫02π​∫0R​ρ3dρdφ=πR2M​∫02π​41​R4dφ=πR2M​2π41​R4=21​MR2​​
0.5.9.6.2 Example: Rolling Cylinder on an Inclined Plane

Consider the following system:

Given a cylinder of radius RRR and mass MMM rolling on an inclined plane with angle α\alphaα, the question can be simplified by considering the following system:

Where α\alphaα is again the angle of the inclined plane, ϕ\phiϕ is the rolling angle of the cylinder, and R=(x,y)R = (x,y)R=(x,y) is the position of the center of mass of the cylinder.

As the cylinder is rolling on the plane with no sliding, we can formulate the constraints as:

y=−Rϕsin⁡(α)x=Rϕcos⁡(α)\begin{align} y &= -R\phi\sin(\alpha) \\ x &= R\phi\cos(\alpha) \end{align}yx​=−Rϕsin(α)=Rϕcos(α)​​

Thus, the velocity of the center of mass of the cylinder is given by:

R˙=(x˙,y˙)=Rϕ˙(cos⁡(α),−sin⁡(α))\begin{align} \dot{R} &= (\dot{x},\dot{y}) \\ &= R\dot{\phi}(\cos(\alpha),-\sin(\alpha)) \end{align}R˙​=(x˙,y˙​)=Rϕ˙​(cos(α),−sin(α))​​

And the kinetic energy TTT of the cylinder is given by:

T=12MR˙2+12Iϕ˙2=12MR2ϕ˙2+12Iϕ˙2=12MR2ϕ˙2+12Iϕ˙2=12MR2ϕ˙2+14MR2ϕ˙2=34MR2ϕ˙2\begin{align} T &= \frac{1}{2}M\dot{R}^2 + \frac{1}{2}I\dot{\phi}^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2}M R^2 \dot{\phi}^2 + \frac{1}{2}I\dot{\phi}^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2}M R^2 \dot{\phi}^2 + \frac{1}{2}I\dot{\phi}^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2}M R^2 \dot{\phi}^2 + \frac{1}{4}M R^2 \dot{\phi}^2 \\ &= \frac{3}{4} M R^2 \dot{\phi}^2 \end{align}T​=21​MR˙2+21​Iϕ˙​2=21​MR2ϕ˙​2+21​Iϕ˙​2=21​MR2ϕ˙​2+21​Iϕ˙​2=21​MR2ϕ˙​2+41​MR2ϕ˙​2=43​MR2ϕ˙​2​​

If we consider a constant gravitational field acting on the cylinder, the potential energy UUU of the cylinder is given by:

U=Mgy=−MgRϕsin⁡(α)U = Mgy = -MgR\phi\sin(\alpha)U=Mgy=−MgRϕsin(α)

The Lagrangian LLL of the cylinder is given by:

L=34MR2ϕ˙2+MgRϕsin⁡(α)L = \frac{3}{4} M R^2 \dot{\phi}^2 + MgR\phi\sin(\alpha)L=43​MR2ϕ˙​2+MgRϕsin(α)

Using the Euler-Lagrange equation, we can determine the equation of motion of the cylinder.

ddt(∂L∂ϕ˙)−∂L∂ϕ=0ddt(32MR2ϕ˙)−MgRsin⁡(α)=032MR2ϕ¨−MgRsin⁡(α)=0ϕ¨=2gsin⁡(α)3R\begin{align} \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\phi}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi} &= 0 \\ \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{3}{2}M R^2 \dot{\phi}\right) - MgR\sin(\alpha) &= 0 \\ \frac{3}{2}M R^2 \ddot{\phi} - MgR\sin(\alpha) &= 0 \\ \ddot{\phi} &= \frac{2g\sin(\alpha)}{3R} \end{align}dtd​(∂ϕ˙​∂L​)−∂ϕ∂L​dtd​(23​MR2ϕ˙​)−MgRsin(α)23​MR2ϕ¨​−MgRsin(α)ϕ¨​​=0=0=0=3R2gsin(α)​​​

0.6 Small Oscillations

0.6.1 Harmonic Oscillator

Given a object with mass mmm, spring constant kkk, and displacement xxx. The kinetic energy TTT of the object is given by:

T=12mx˙2T = \frac{1}{2}m\dot{x}^2T=21​mx˙2

The potential energy UUU of the object is given by:

U=12kx2U = \frac{1}{2}kx^2U=21​kx2

The Lagrangian LLL of the object is given by:

L=T−U=12mx˙2−12kx2L = T - U = \frac{1}{2}m\dot{x}^2 - \frac{1}{2}kx^2L=T−U=21​mx˙2−21​kx2

By solving the Euler-Lagrange equation, we can determine the equation of motion of the object.

ddt(∂L∂x˙)−∂L∂x=0ddt(mx˙)+kx=0mx¨+kx=0\begin{align} \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial x} &= 0 \\ \frac{d}{dt}\left(m\dot{x}\right) + kx &= 0 \\ m\ddot{x} + kx &= 0 \end{align}dtd​(∂x˙∂L​)−∂x∂L​dtd​(mx˙)+kxmx¨+kx​=0=0=0​​

Thus,

x=Acos⁡(ωt+ϕ),ω=kmx = A \cos(\omega t + \phi), \omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}x=Acos(ωt+ϕ),ω=mk​​

0.6.2 Small Oscillations in General

Given a system with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and potential energy UUU of the system. And stationary points qi0q_{i0}qi0​ of potential energy UUU. Such that

∂U∂qi=0\frac{\partial U}{\partial q_i} = 0∂qi​∂U​=0

Then, the potential energy UUU can be expanded as a Taylor series around the stationary points qi0q_{i0}qi0​.

U=U(qi0)+∑i∂U∂qi(qi−qi0)+12∑i,j∂2U∂qi∂qj(qi−qi0)(qj−qj0)+⋯=U(qi0)+12∑i,j∂2U∂qi∂qj(qi−qi0)(qj−qj0)+⋯≈U(qi0)+12∑i,j∂2U∂qi∂qj(qi−qi0)(qj−qj0)\begin{align} U &= U(q_{i0}) + \sum_i \frac{\partial U}{\partial q_i}(q_i - q_{i0}) + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i,j} \frac{\partial^2 U}{\partial q_i \partial q_j}(q_i - q_{i0})(q_j - q_{j0}) + \cdots \\ &= U(q_{i0}) + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i,j} \frac{\partial^2 U}{\partial q_i \partial q_j}(q_i - q_{i0})(q_j - q_{j0}) + \cdots \\ &\approx U(q_{i0}) + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i,j} \frac{\partial^2 U}{\partial q_i \partial q_j}(q_i - q_{i0})(q_j - q_{j0}) \end{align}U​=U(qi0​)+i∑​∂qi​∂U​(qi​−qi0​)+21​i,j∑​∂qi​∂qj​∂2U​(qi​−qi0​)(qj​−qj0​)+⋯=U(qi0​)+21​i,j∑​∂qi​∂qj​∂2U​(qi​−qi0​)(qj​−qj0​)+⋯≈U(qi0​)+21​i,j∑​∂qi​∂qj​∂2U​(qi​−qi0​)(qj​−qj0​)​​

We could use symmetric matrix KKK to represent the second order partial derivatives of the potential energy UUU.

Kij=∂2U∂qi∂qjK_{ij} = \frac{\partial^2 U}{\partial q_i \partial q_j}Kij​=∂qi​∂qj​∂2U​

Thus, the potential energy UUU can be expressed as:

U=U(qi0)+12(q−q0)TK(q−q0)U = U(q_{i0}) + \frac{1}{2}(q-q_{0})^T K (q-q_{0})U=U(qi0​)+21​(q−q0​)TK(q−q0​)

Also, in general, the kinetic energy TTT of the system can be expressed using a positive definite symmetric matrix MMM.

T=12q˙TMq˙T = \frac{1}{2}\dot{q}^T M \dot{q}T=21​q˙​TMq˙​

Thus, in general, the Lagrangian LLL of the system is given by:

L=T−U=12q˙TMq˙−U(qi0)−12(q−q0)TK(q−q0)L = T - U = \frac{1}{2}\dot{q}^T M \dot{q} - U(q_{i0}) - \frac{1}{2}(q-q_{0})^T K (q-q_{0})L=T−U=21​q˙​TMq˙​−U(qi0​)−21​(q−q0​)TK(q−q0​)

0.6.3 Double Pendulum

Consider a double pendulum like below:

Thus, the stationary points of the double pendulum are given by:

φ1=0φ2=0\begin{align} \varphi_1 &= 0 \\ \varphi_2 &= 0 \end{align}φ1​φ2​​=0=0​​

If we set the suspension point as the origin (0,0)(0,0)(0,0), then the position of the first mass m1m_1m1​ is given by:

x1=l1sin⁡(φ1)y1=−l1cos⁡(φ1)\begin{align} x_1 &= l_1\sin(\varphi_1) \\ y_1 &= -l_1\cos(\varphi_1) \end{align}x1​y1​​=l1​sin(φ1​)=−l1​cos(φ1​)​​

And the position of the second mass m2m_2m2​ is given by:

x2=l1sin⁡(φ1)+l2sin⁡(φ2)y2=−l1cos⁡(φ1)−l2cos⁡(φ2)\begin{align} x_2 &= l_1\sin(\varphi_1) + l_2\sin(\varphi_2) \\ y_2 &= -l_1\cos(\varphi_1) - l_2\cos(\varphi_2) \end{align}x2​y2​​=l1​sin(φ1​)+l2​sin(φ2​)=−l1​cos(φ1​)−l2​cos(φ2​)​​

Thus, if we set φ1\varphi_1φ1​ and φ2\varphi_2φ2​ close to the stationary point, the kinetic energy TTT of the double pendulum is given by:

T=12m1(x˙12+y˙12)+12m2(x˙22+y˙22)=12m1(l12φ˙12)+12m2(l12φ˙12+l22φ˙22+2l1l2φ˙1φ˙2cos⁡(φ1−φ2))≈12m1l12φ˙12+12m2l12φ˙12+12m2l22φ˙22+m2l1l2φ˙1φ˙2\begin{align} T &= \frac{1}{2}m_1\left(\dot{x}_1^2 + \dot{y}_1^2\right) + \frac{1}{2}m_2\left(\dot{x}_2^2 + \dot{y}_2^2\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{2}m_1\left(l_1^2\dot{\varphi}_1^2\right) + \frac{1}{2}m_2\left(l_1^2\dot{\varphi}_1^2 + l_2^2\dot{\varphi}_2^2 + 2l_1l_2\dot{\varphi}_1\dot{\varphi}_2\cos(\varphi_1 - \varphi_2)\right) \\ &\approx \frac{1}{2}m_1l_1^2\dot{\varphi}_1^2 + \frac{1}{2}m_2l_1^2\dot{\varphi}_1^2 + \frac{1}{2}m_2l_2^2\dot{\varphi}_2^2 + m_2l_1l_2\dot{\varphi}_1\dot{\varphi}_2 \end{align}T​=21​m1​(x˙12​+y˙​12​)+21​m2​(x˙22​+y˙​22​)=21​m1​(l12​φ˙​12​)+21​m2​(l12​φ˙​12​+l22​φ˙​22​+2l1​l2​φ˙​1​φ˙​2​cos(φ1​−φ2​))≈21​m1​l12​φ˙​12​+21​m2​l12​φ˙​12​+21​m2​l22​φ˙​22​+m2​l1​l2​φ˙​1​φ˙​2​​​

The potential energy UUU of the double pendulum is given by:

U=m1gy1+m2gy2=−m1gl1cos⁡(φ1)−m2gl1cos⁡(φ1)−m2gl2cos⁡(φ2)≈−(m1gl1+m2gl1)(1−12φ12)−m2gl2(1−12φ22)\begin{align} U &= m_1gy_1 + m_2gy_2 \\ &= -m_1gl_1\cos(\varphi_1) - m_2gl_1\cos(\varphi_1) - m_2gl_2\cos(\varphi_2) \\ &\approx -(m_1gl_1 + m_2gl_1)(1-\frac{1}{2}\varphi_1^2) - m_2gl_2(1-\frac{1}{2}\varphi_2^2) \end{align}U​=m1​gy1​+m2​gy2​=−m1​gl1​cos(φ1​)−m2​gl1​cos(φ1​)−m2​gl2​cos(φ2​)≈−(m1​gl1​+m2​gl1​)(1−21​φ12​)−m2​gl2​(1−21​φ22​)​​

0.7 Normal Modes

As in Small Oscillations in General, we can express the kinetic and potential energy of the system in terms of symmetric matrices MMM and KKK:

T=12q˙TMq˙U=12(q−q0)TK(q−q0)\begin{align} T &= \frac{1}{2}\dot{q}^T M \dot{q} \\ U &= \frac{1}{2}(q-q_{0})^T K (q-q_{0}) \end{align}TU​=21​q˙​TMq˙​=21​(q−q0​)TK(q−q0​)​​

Thus, the general momentum ppp of the system is given by:

p=∂L∂q˙=Mq˙p = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}} = M\dot{q}p=∂q˙​∂L​=Mq˙​

And the generalised force QQQ of the system is given by:

Q=∂L∂q=K(q−q0)Q = \frac{\partial L}{\partial q} = K(q-q_{0})Q=∂q∂L​=K(q−q0​)

And the Euler-Lagrange equation is given by:

ddt(∂L∂q˙)−∂L∂q=0ddt(Mq˙)−K(q−q0)=0Mq¨+K(q−q0)=0\begin{align} \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial q} &= 0 \\ \frac{d}{dt}\left(M\dot{q}\right) - K(q-q_{0}) &= 0 \\ M\ddot{q} + K(q-q_{0}) &= 0 \end{align}dtd​(∂q˙​∂L​)−∂q∂L​dtd​(Mq˙​)−K(q−q0​)Mq¨​+K(q−q0​)​=0=0=0​​

As, MMM is a positive definite symmetric matrix, the inverse of MMM exists.

Thus, the equation of motion of the system can be expressed as:

q¨+M−1K(q−q0)=0\ddot{q} + M^{-1}K(q-q_{0}) = 0q¨​+M−1K(q−q0​)=0

A normal mode of the system is a solution of the above equation of the form:

q(t)=q0+c(t)vq(t) = q_0 + c(t)vq(t)=q0​+c(t)v

Where c(t)c(t)c(t) is a scalar function of time, and vvv is a vector that is independent of time.

Substituting the normal mode solution into the equation of motion of the system:

q¨+M−1K(q−q0)=0c¨(t)v+c(t)M−1K(v)=0c¨c(t)v+M−1K(v)=0\begin{align} \ddot{q} + M^{-1}K(q-q_{0}) &= 0 \\ \ddot{c}(t)v + c(t)M^{-1}K(v) &= 0 \\ \frac{\ddot{c}}{c(t)} v + M^{-1}K(v) &= 0 \end{align}q¨​+M−1K(q−q0​)c¨(t)v+c(t)M−1K(v)c(t)c¨​v+M−1K(v)​=0=0=0​​

Thus, vvv is an eigenvector of the matrix M−1KM^{-1}KM−1K with eigenvalue ω2\omega^2ω2, where ω\omegaω is the angular frequency of the normal mode. And, c(t)c(t)c(t) is a solution of the following ODE:

c¨+ω2c=0\ddot{c} + \omega^2 c = 0c¨+ω2c=0

Thus, the general solution of the normal mode is given by:

q(t)=q0+∑icivicos⁡(ωit+ϕi)q(t) = q_0 + \sum_i c_i v_i \cos(\omega_i t + \phi_i)q(t)=q0​+i∑​ci​vi​cos(ωi​t+ϕi​)

0.8 Hamiltonian Mechanics

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Lagrangian LLL of the system, the generalised momentum pip_ipi​ of the system is given by:

pi=∂L∂q˙ip_i = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_i}pi​=∂q˙​i​∂L​

And we can solve this implicit equation to get q˙i\dot{q}_iq˙​i​ in terms of qiq_iqi​ and pip_ipi​.

The Hamiltonian HHH of the system is given by:

H=p⋅q˙(q,p,t)−L(q,q˙(q,p,t),t)H = p \cdot \dot{q}(q,p,t) - L(q,\dot{q}(q,p,t),t)H=p⋅q˙​(q,p,t)−L(q,q˙​(q,p,t),t)

0.8.1 Hamilton's Canonical Equations

By the Euler-Lagrange equation, we can derive the following equations:

dHdp=q˙+p⋅dq˙p−dLdq˙⋅dq˙p=q˙+p⋅dq˙p−pdq˙p=q˙\begin{align} \frac{dH}{dp} &= \dot{q} + p \cdot \frac{d\dot{q}}{p} - \frac{dL}{d\dot{q}}\cdot \frac{d\dot{q}}{p} \\ &= \dot{q} + p \cdot \frac{d\dot{q}}{p} - p \frac{d\dot{q}}{p} \\ &= \dot{q} \end{align}dpdH​​=q˙​+p⋅pdq˙​​−dq˙​dL​⋅pdq˙​​=q˙​+p⋅pdq˙​​−ppdq˙​​=q˙​​​ dHdq=dpdq⋅q˙+p⋅dq˙dq−dLdq−dLdq˙dq˙dq=dpdq⋅q˙+p⋅dq˙dq−p˙−pdq˙dq=−p˙\begin{align} \frac{dH}{dq} &= \frac{dp}{dq} \cdot \dot{q} + p \cdot \frac{d\dot{q}}{dq} - \frac{dL}{dq} - \frac{dL}{d\dot{q}}\frac{d\dot{q}}{dq}\\ &= \frac{dp}{dq} \cdot \dot{q} + p \cdot \frac{d\dot{q}}{dq} - \dot{p} -p \frac{d\dot{q}}{dq}\\ &= -\dot{p} \end{align}dqdH​​=dqdp​⋅q˙​+p⋅dqdq˙​​−dqdL​−dq˙​dL​dqdq˙​​=dqdp​⋅q˙​+p⋅dqdq˙​​−p˙​−pdqdq˙​​=−p˙​​​

0.8.2 Quadratic Hamiltonian

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, if the potential energy is independent of q˙\dot{q}q˙​, and the kinetic energy TTT of the system is quadratic in the generalized velocities q˙i\dot{q}_iq˙​i​, which means there is a positive definite symmetric matrix M=M(q,t)M = M(q,t)M=M(q,t) such that:

T=12q˙TMq˙T = \frac{1}{2}\dot{q}^T M \dot{q}T=21​q˙​TMq˙​

Then the Hamiltonian HHH of the system is given by:

H=p⋅q˙−L=∂L∂q˙⋅q˙−T+U=∂T∂q˙⋅q˙−T+U=(Mq˙)⋅q˙−T+U=T+U\begin{align} H &= p \cdot \dot{q} - L \\ &= \frac{\partial L}{\partial\dot{q}} \cdot \dot{q} - T + U \\ &= \frac{\partial T}{\partial\dot{q}} \cdot \dot{q} - T + U \\ &= (M\dot{q}) \cdot \dot{q} -T + U \\ &= T + U \\ \end{align}H​=p⋅q˙​−L=∂q˙​∂L​⋅q˙​−T+U=∂q˙​∂T​⋅q˙​−T+U=(Mq˙​)⋅q˙​−T+U=T+U​​

0.8.3 Example: Harmonic Oscillator

Given a object with mass mmm, spring constant kkk, and displacement xxx.

The momentum ppp of the object is given by:

p=∂L∂x˙=mx˙p = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}} = m\dot{x}p=∂x˙∂L​=mx˙

Thus,

x˙=pm\dot{x} = \frac{p}{m}x˙=mp​

The potential energy UUU of the object is given by:

U=12kx2U = \frac{1}{2}kx^2U=21​kx2

The kinetic energy TTT of the object is given by:

T=12mx˙2=12m(pm)2=p22mT = \frac{1}{2}m\dot{x}^2 = \frac{1}{2}m\left(\frac{p}{m}\right)^2 = \frac{p^2}{2m}T=21​mx˙2=21​m(mp​)2=2mp2​

As the potential energy UUU is independent of x˙\dot{x}x˙, and the kinetic energy TTT is quadratic in x˙\dot{x}x˙, the Hamiltonian HHH of the object is given by:

H=T+U=p22m+12kx2H = T + U = \frac{p^2}{2m} + \frac{1}{2}kx^2H=T+U=2mp2​+21​kx2

By Hamilton's canonical equations, we can determine the equation of motion of the object.

∂H∂p=x˙=pm∂H∂x=−p˙kx=−p˙mx¨=−kx\begin{align} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p} &= \dot{x} = \frac{p}{m} \\ \frac{\partial H}{\partial x} &= -\dot{p} \\ kx &= -\dot{p} \\ m\ddot{x} &= -kx \end{align}∂p∂H​∂x∂H​kxmx¨​=x˙=mp​=−p˙​=−p˙​=−kx​​

0.8.4 Cyclical Coordinates in Hamiltonian Mechanics

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​.

If the Hamiltonian HHH does not depend on a generalized coordinate qiq_iqi​, then the generalized coordinate qiq_iqi​ is called a cyclical coordinate.

Thus,

p˙=−∂H∂qi=0\dot{p} = -\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_i} = 0p˙​=−∂qi​∂H​=0

The momentum pip_ipi​ is conserved.

If the Hamiltonian HHH does not depend on a momentum pip_ipi​, then the momentum pip_ipi​ is called a cyclical momentum.

Thus,

q˙=∂H∂pi=0\dot{q} = \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_i} = 0q˙​=∂pi​∂H​=0

The generalized coordinate qiq_iqi​ is conserved.

0.8.5 Example: Particle on a Cone

Consider the following system:

The cone is given by:

z=x2+y2z = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}z=x2+y2​

The mass of the particle is mmm, the cone is smooth.

Consider the following generalized coordinates:

z=z\begin{align} z &= z \\ \end{align}z​=z​​

And φ\varphiφ be the angle of the projection of the particle on the xyxyxy plane with the xxx axis.

Then,

x=zcos⁡(φ)y=zsin⁡(φ)z=z\begin{align} x &= z\cos(\varphi) \\ y &= z\sin(\varphi) \\ z &= z \end{align}xyz​=zcos(φ)=zsin(φ)=z​​

The kinetic energy TTT of the particle is given by:

T=12m(x˙2+y˙2+z˙2)=12m(z2φ˙2+z˙2+z˙2)=12m(2z˙2+z2φ˙2)\begin{align} T &= \frac{1}{2}m(\dot{x}^2 + \dot{y}^2 + \dot{z}^2) \\ &= \frac{1}{2}m(z^2\dot{\varphi}^2 + \dot{z}^2 + \dot{z}^2) \\ &= \frac{1}{2}m(2\dot{z}^2 + z^2\dot{\varphi}^2) \end{align}T​=21​m(x˙2+y˙​2+z˙2)=21​m(z2φ˙​2+z˙2+z˙2)=21​m(2z˙2+z2φ˙​2)​​

The potential energy UUU of the particle is given by:

U=mgzU = mgzU=mgz

Thus, the Lagrangian LLL of the particle is given by:

L=T−U=12m(2z˙2+z2φ˙2)−mgzL = T - U = \frac{1}{2}m(2\dot{z}^2 + z^2\dot{\varphi}^2) - mgzL=T−U=21​m(2z˙2+z2φ˙​2)−mgz

The momentum of the particle is given by:

pz=∂L∂z˙=2mz˙pφ=∂L∂φ˙=mz2φ˙\begin{align} p_{z} &= \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{z}} = 2m\dot{z} \\ p_{\varphi} &= \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}} = mz^2\dot{\varphi} \end{align}pz​pφ​​=∂z˙∂L​=2mz˙=∂φ˙​∂L​=mz2φ˙​​​

Thus,

z˙=pz2mφ˙=pφmz2\begin{align} \dot{z} &= \frac{p_z}{2m} \\ \dot{\varphi} &= \frac{p_{\varphi}}{mz^2} \end{align}z˙φ˙​​=2mpz​​=mz2pφ​​​​

The Hamiltonian HHH of the particle is given by:

H=p⋅q˙−L=pzz˙+pφφ˙−L=pzpz2m+pφpφmz2−12m(2z˙2+z2φ˙2)+mgz=pz22m+pφ2mz2−12m(2(pz2m)2+z2(pφmz2)2)+mgz=pz22m+pφ2mz2−pz24m−pφ22mz2+mgz=pz24m+pφ22mz2+mgz\begin{align} H &= p \cdot \dot{q} - L \\ &= p_z\dot{z} + p_{\varphi}\dot{\varphi} - L \\ &= p_z\frac{p_z}{2m} + p_{\varphi}\frac{p_{\varphi}}{mz^2} - \frac{1}{2}m(2\dot{z}^2 + z^2\dot{\varphi}^2) + mgz \\ &= \frac{p_z^2}{2m} + \frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{mz^2} - \frac{1}{2}m\left(2\left(\frac{p_z}{2m}\right)^2 + z^2\left(\frac{p_{\varphi}}{mz^2}\right)^2\right) + mgz \\ &= \frac{p_z^2}{2m} + \frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{mz^2} - \frac{p_z^2}{4m} - \frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz \\ &= \frac{p_z^2}{4m} + \frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz \end{align}H​=p⋅q˙​−L=pz​z˙+pφ​φ˙​−L=pz​2mpz​​+pφ​mz2pφ​​−21​m(2z˙2+z2φ˙​2)+mgz=2mpz2​​+mz2pφ2​​−21​m(2(2mpz​​)2+z2(mz2pφ​​)2)+mgz=2mpz2​​+mz2pφ2​​−4mpz2​​−2mz2pφ2​​+mgz=4mpz2​​+2mz2pφ2​​+mgz​​

As the Hamiltonian HHH does not depend on the generalized coordinate φ\varphiφ, the generalized coordinate φ\varphiφ is a cyclical coordinate. And the momentum pφp_{\varphi}pφ​ is a constant.

Thus,

dHdpϕ=φ˙pϕmz2=φ˙\begin{align} \frac{dH}{dp_{\phi}} &= \dot{\varphi} \\ \frac{p_{\phi}}{mz^2} &= \dot{\varphi} \\ \end{align}dpϕ​dH​mz2pϕ​​​=φ˙​=φ˙​​​

For zzz coordinate,

dHdpz=z˙pz2m=z˙\begin{align} \frac{dH}{dp_{z}} &= \dot{z} \\ \frac{p_{z}}{2m} &= \dot{z} \\ \end{align}dpz​dH​2mpz​​​=z˙=z˙​​

If we are given the initial energy of the particle EEE, then the Hamiltonian HHH of the particle is given by:

E=pz24m+pφ22mz2+mgz=mz˙2+pφ22mz2+mgz\begin{align} E &= \frac{p_z^2}{4m} + \frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz \\ &= m\dot{z}^2 + \frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz \end{align}E​=4mpz2​​+2mz2pφ2​​+mgz=mz˙2+2mz2pφ2​​+mgz​​

Which became a first order separable ODE in zzz.

If pφ=0p_{\varphi} = 0pφ​=0, then the particle is moving vertically just like sliding on a smooth surface.

If pφ≠0p_{\varphi} \neq 0pφ​=0, then the term pφ22mz2+mgz\frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz2mz2pφ2​​+mgz has lowest energy at z0=pφm2g3z_0 = \sqrt[3]{\frac{p_{\varphi}}{m^2g}}z0​=3m2gpφ​​​ with energy E0E_0E0​.

If E=E0E = E_0E=E0​, then mz˙2=0m\dot{z}^2 = 0mz˙2=0, and the particle is doing a circular motion on the cone.

If E>E0E > E_0E>E0​, then the particle is doing oscillatory motion on the cone. By using Taylor expansion of pφ22mz2+mgz\frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz2mz2pφ2​​+mgz around z0z_0z0​, We could derive:

mz˙2+E0+12(pφ22mz2+mgz)′′∣z0(z−z0)2≈Em\dot{z}^2 + E_0 + \frac{1}{2}\left.(\frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz)''\right|_{z_{0}} (z-z_0)^2 \approx Emz˙2+E0​+21​(2mz2pφ2​​+mgz)′′​z0​​(z−z0​)2≈E

And we could expect the angular frequency of the oscillatory motion to be approximately:

ω=12m(pφ22mz2+mgz)′′∣z0\omega = \sqrt{\frac{1}{2m}\left.(\frac{p_{\varphi}^2}{2mz^2} + mgz)''\right|_{z_{0}}}ω=2m1​(2mz2pφ2​​+mgz)′′​z0​​​

0.8.6 Phase Space

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Hamiltonian HHH of the system, the phase space Γ\GammaΓ of the system is the space of generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​ and momenta pip_ipi​.

The phase space of the system is a 2n2n2n dimensional space, where nnn is the number of generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​.

0.8.6.1 Hamiltonian Flow

The trajectory of the system together with the change of the momentum of the system, generate a path in ttt in the phase space of the system, and the Hamiltonian canonical equations describe the flow of the system in the phase space.

dqidt=∂H∂pidpidt=−∂H∂qi\begin{align} \frac{dq_i}{dt} &= \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_i} \\ \frac{dp_i}{dt} &= -\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_i} \end{align}dtdqi​​dtdpi​​​=∂pi​∂H​=−∂qi​∂H​​​

0.8.6.2 Liouville's Theorem

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Hamiltonian HHH of the system, the volume of the phase space of the system is conserved. In other words, the Hamiltonian flow of the system is incompressible.

dVdt=0\frac{dV}{dt} = 0dtdV​=0

0.8.6.3 Phase Space Portrait

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Hamiltonian HHH of the system, the phase space portrait of the system is the plot of the trajectory of the system in the phase space of the system.

0.8.6.3.1 Example: Phase Space Portrait of a Harmonic Oscillator

Given a object with mass mmm, spring constant kkk, and displacement xxx. The Hamiltonian HHH of the object is given by:

H=p22m+12kx2H = \frac{p^2}{2m} + \frac{1}{2}kx^2H=2mp2​+21​kx2

The Phase Space Portrait of the object is like:

0.8.7 Poisson Brackets

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Hamiltonian HHH of the system, the Poisson bracket of two functions fff and ggg of the phase space of the system is given by:

{f,g}=∑i(∂f∂qi∂g∂pi−∂f∂pi∂g∂qi)\{f,g\} = \sum_i \left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial q_i}\frac{\partial g}{\partial p_i} - \frac{\partial f}{\partial p_i}\frac{\partial g}{\partial q_i}\right){f,g}=i∑​(∂qi​∂f​∂pi​∂g​−∂pi​∂f​∂qi​∂g​)

0.8.7.1 Properties of Poisson Brackets

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Hamiltonian HHH of the system, the Poisson bracket of two functions fff and ggg of the phase space of the system has the following properties:

  1. Antisymmetry: {f,g}=−{g,f}\{f,g\} = -\{g,f\}{f,g}=−{g,f}
  2. Linearity: {af+bg,h}=a{f,h}+b{g,h}\{af + bg, h\} = a\{f,h\} + b\{g,h\}{af+bg,h}=a{f,h}+b{g,h}
  3. Product(Leibnitz) Rule: {fg,h}=f{g,h}+g{f,h}\{fg,h\} = f\{g,h\} + g\{f,h\}{fg,h}=f{g,h}+g{f,h}

0.8.7.2 Fundamental Poisson Brackets

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Hamiltonian HHH of the system, the fundamental Poisson brackets of the system are given by:

{qi,pj}=δij{qi,qj}=0{pi,pj}=0\begin{align} \{q_i,p_j\} &= \delta_{ij} \\ \{q_i,q_j\} &= 0 \\ \{p_i,p_j\} &= 0 \end{align}{qi​,pj​}{qi​,qj​}{pi​,pj​}​=δij​=0=0​​

0.8.7.3 Constant of Motion and Poisson Brackets

Given a system of particles with generalized coordinates qiq_iqi​, and the Hamiltonian HHH of the system, and a function fff of the phase space of the system, then time derivative of the function fff is given by:

dfdt={f,H}+∂f∂t\begin{align} \frac{df}{dt} &= \{f,H\} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial t} \end{align}dtdf​​={f,H}+∂t∂f​​​

Thus, if the function fff is independent of time, then the function fff is a constant of motion.
